## Introduction

This research applies international accounting frameworks and standards for Natural Capital Accounting in Hawai ªi- The [UN System of Environmental- Economic Accounts](https://seea.un.org/ecosystem-accounting/) and the [IUCN Global Ecosystem Typology (GET) 2.0.](https://iucn.org/resources/conservation-tool/iucn-global-ecosystem-typology)

The aim is to create ecosystem accounts that track annual changes to Hawaiian ecosystems in a consistent way. This allows policy makers, conservation managers, and interested parties, to track and compare changes in ecosystem extents and conditions over time and across different geographies in the Main Hawaiian Islands and the world.

## Preliminary Findings

-   Ideally ecosystems are best classified by Ecosystem Functional Groups according to IUCN. However, multiple research and data limitations persist in Hawai ªi.

-   Crucially, most ecological/ biological research do not cover the entire area of the Main Hawaiian Islands (MHI) nor are they routinely updated over long periods of time.

-   In Hawai ªi, some functional groups (eg. Tropical/Subtropical lowland rainforests) are better studied than others (eg. Anchialine caves)

## Ecosystem Conditions (Terrestrial)

Pilot ecosystem condition accounts show changes to ecosystem types based on four condition variables for years 2013, 2016, and 2019-

1.  Area burnt;
2.  Rainfall;
3.  Temperature;
4.  NDVI ("vegetation greenness")

------------------------------------------------------------------------

## Rainfall Conditions (Tree Cover)

Many Moku have seen significant drop in rainfall over the forests:

![](images/tree_rain-02.png){fig-align="center"}

## Rainfall Conditions (Tree Cover)

This graph calculates the difference in mean monthly rainfall- comparing baseline (1990-1992) to 2019 rainfall for tree cover ecosystem type:

![](images/tree_rain_chge.png){fig-align="center"}

## Temperature Conditions (Tree Cover)

In forests, mean annual temperatures have risen far more between 2013 to 2019 as compared to the baseline (1990-1992).

![](images/tree_temp.png){fig-align="center"}

## Temperature Conditions

Large temperature increases were recorded primarily in the big island forests:

![](images/tree_temp_chge.png){fig-align="center"}

## NDVI Conditions

Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) makes use of the near-infrared and red bands of the EM spectrum to determine "greenness" of an area (ranging from -1 to 1). High values can mean denser vegetation:

![](images/tree_ndvi.png){fig-align="center"}

## NDVI Conditions

Forests in central Maui appear to have negative scores compared to the baseline, while most moku have recorded increases in 2019 compared to the baseline (2001-2003):

![](images/tree_ndvi_chge.png){fig-align="center"}

Currently, there is no comprehensive data on IUCN EFG T1.2 (Tropical/Subtropical dry forests and thickets) across the MHI. However, we can identify likely areas within tree cover ecosystem type by examining rainfall conditions. Taking rainfall patterns across tree cover in Kona, O ªahu in 2013:

We can identify areas within the tree cover ecosystem type that has less than 1,800mm of annual rainfall and 3-6 consecutive months of \<100mm rainfall, that are likely dry forests & thickets.

## Extinction Risk as LIFE Metric

Many species are adapted to and dependent on a historic ("human absent") range and are affected by changes in current habitat in relation to that historic range. The LIFE metric lets us calculate a comparable and scalable extinction risk across species, space and time [(Eyres et al., 2025)](https://royalsocietypublishing.org/doi/10.1098/rstb.2023.0327).

## LIFE Metric (EFG T1.2)

In this example, we use our ecosystem extent accounts to study modern changes in relation to historic ("human absent") EFG T1.2 maps provided by IUCN. We focus on Kau, Hawai ªi Island since it is the moku with the largest historic extent of dry forests and thickets.

![](images/Screenshot%202025-08-27%20at%2013.40.51.png){fig-align="center"}

## EFG T1.2 in Kau

We see that Kau moku has seen the largest proportionate decrease in EFG T1.2 compared to other moku in the MHI, due to relatively wetter conditions.

![](images/mapt1.2_chge.png){fig-align="center"}

## EFG T1.2 in Kau from 2013 to 2019

Even though Kau had the second largest increase in tree cover ecosystem type across moku in the MHI. It had the steepest decline in EFG T1.2, due to wetter conditions. The maps (left to right) below show its historic range, 2013 extent, and 2019 extent.

## LIFE Score Calculation

The LIFE score, which considers changes in suitable habitat (within historic range; in the numerator) as well as its historic extents (in denominator) can then be computed according to Eyres et al., (2025)-

$$
\left(\frac{54.41}{1338.24}\right)^{0.25}-\left(\frac{108.48}{1338.24}\right)^{0.25}\approx -0.08 
$$

## Ease of Comparison

LIFE scores can be easily compared and summed. For example, a similar analysis was done for EFG T1.2 in **Kona, O ªahu** from 2013 to 2019, resulting in a positive **LIFE score of 0.07**. If we sum Kona, O ªahu and Kau, Hawai ªi's score (-0.08), the **overall score is -0.01**. Showing that overall extinction risk for species dependent on EFG T1.2 increased when both moku are aggregated.
